text: It is not any shame to flie, from ill, although by night:
Knowne ill, he better does that flies, then he it takes in fight.
Better from Evils, well foreseen, to run,
Than perish in the Danger we may shun.
Wiser him I deem
Who ’scapes his foe, than whom his foe enthralls.
It is better for a flying man to escape from evil, than to be taken.
better is his fate
Who flees from harm than his whom harm o'ertakes.
To fly from evil no dishonor is.
E'en in the night ; far better so to do,
Than that our army should all captured be.
It is better for a man that he should fly and be saved than be caught and killed.
Better it is if one fleeth from ruin and escapeth, than if he be taken.
Better fight and run away than tarry to be caught next day.
It’s better to save one’s skin by running than to be caught.
The man does better who runs from disaster than he who is caught by it.
The quicker you run, I say, the longer you live!
Far better to flee and escape
Than stay and be taken.
Better a man
should leave the worst behind him than be caught.
better to run and escape disaster than be caught in it.
Better to flee from death than feel its grip.
Better to give evil the slip than be caught by it.
It’s better to escape one’s own destruction—
to run off—than let it overtake you.
Better to flee and save ourselves than be taken.
it is better for a man to flee and escape ruin than to be captured.
It is better to run and escape death than to be killed here.
Escape by flight is better than getting caught.
it is better that a fleeing man escape evil than is captured.
You see, when things go wrong,
escape is better than captivity.
